laws.summary: Colorado heavily restricts non-compete agreements. C.R.S. § 8-2-113 generally prohibits non-competes except for: (1) executives earning $112,500+ (threshold adjusted for inflation), (2) purchase/sale of business, (3) recovery of training expenses for specialized training (max 2 years), (4) trade secrets protection. Colorado is very employee-friendly on non-competes.
laws.notes: Colorado is most restrictive state on non-competes. Very narrow exceptions. Federal FTC ban blocked but Colorado law already more restrictive.
laws.law_citation: C.R.S. § 8-2-113 (Covenant Not to Compete); C.R.S. § 8-2-113.5 (Medical Non-Competes)
laws.full_text:
GENERAL RULE: Non-competes are VOID and unenforceable
EXCEPTION 1: Executives and professional staff earning threshold amount or more (2026: approx. $112,500 adjusted annually for inflation)
EXCEPTION 2: Purchase and sale of business or business assets
EXCEPTION 3: Recovery of training expenses for specialized training (max 2 years if education/training costs paid by employer)
EXCEPTION 4: Protect trade secrets (narrow exception)
PHYSICIANS: Medical non-competes further restricted by C.R.S. § 8-2-113.5 - can only enforce upon sale of practice or in limited circumstances
Non-solicitation agreements: Generally more enforceable than full non-competes, but still scrutinized
Customer non-solicitation: May be enforceable if reasonable
Employee non-solicitation: May be enforceable if reasonable
Confidentiality agreements: Enforceable
Courts will NOT blue-pencil unreasonable agreements - void entirely if overreaching
Violators may face damages and attorney fees
laws.suggestion: Review Colorado non-compete requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Colorado prohibits employers from asking about salary history. Under the Equal Pay for Equal Work Act, employers cannot seek wage history from applicants or rely on it in determining compensation. Applies to all Colorado employers.
laws.notes: Colorado salary history ban is part of comprehensive pay equity law.
laws.law_citation: C.R.S. § 8-5-201 et seq. (Equal Pay for Equal Work Act)
laws.full_text:
Employers cannot seek wage rate history from job applicants
Cannot screen applicants based on wage history
Cannot require wage history disclosure
Cannot rely on wage history to determine wages
Cannot retaliate against employees for discussing wages
Applicant may voluntarily disclose without prompting
If voluntarily disclosed, employer may verify and consider but cannot rely solely on it
Applies to all Colorado employers regardless of size
Violations subject to civil penalties
Effective January 1, 2021
laws.suggestion: Review Colorado salary history requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Colorado has STRONG pay transparency requirements under the Equal Pay for Equal Work Act. Employers must include compensation and benefits in ALL job postings (including remote positions). Must notify employees of promotional opportunities. Must disclose pay rates upon request.
laws.notes: Colorado has one of strongest pay transparency laws in U.S. Applies to remote positions. Many national employers post salary ranges to comply.
laws.law_citation: C.R.S. § 8-5-201 et seq. (Equal Pay for Equal Work Act)
laws.full_text:
ALL JOB POSTINGS must include: hourly rate or salary compensation (or range), general description of bonuses/commissions/other compensation, general description of benefits
Applies to ALL Colorado employers with at least 1 employee in Colorado
Includes remote positions if employee will work in Colorado
Promotional opportunities: Must notify all current employees of job openings before making hiring decision
Career progression: Employers with 15+ employees must make reasonable efforts to inform employees of career progression opportunities
Upon request or job offer: Must disclose compensation range and benefits for position
Pay range must be what employer 'reasonably and in good faith believes' it will pay
Cannot have different ranges for substantially similar work unless justified by seniority, merit, geographic location, education/training/experience, or travel requirements
Annual reporting: Employers with 50+ employees must keep records and may be required to report compensation data
Violations: Civil penalties, employee right to sue for damages and attorney fees
Effective January 1, 2021
laws.suggestion: Review Colorado pay transparency requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Colorado has ban-the-box protections. Employers cannot ask about criminal history on initial application. Cannot inquire until later in hiring process. Must comply with federal FCRA and Colorado's fair credit reporting requirements.
laws.notes: Colorado has ban-the-box protections. Cannot ask about arrests without conviction. Federal FCRA also applies.
laws.law_citation: C.R.S. § 8-2-108 (Criminal History in Applications); C.R.S. § 8-3-108 (Arrests Without Conviction); Federal FCRA (15 U.S.C. § 1681)
laws.full_text:
Cannot include questions about criminal history on initial employment application
Cannot inquire about criminal history until after application is submitted
Cannot inquire about arrests that did not result in conviction (C.R.S. § 8-3-108)
Timing: Can ask about criminal history during interview or after conditional offer
Must provide notice before conducting background check
Must get written authorization for background check
FCRA: Must provide pre-adverse action notice with copy of report
FCRA: Must provide final adverse action notice
FCRA: Seven-year lookback for most non-conviction records
Must conduct individualized assessment
Must consider: nature/gravity of offense, time elapsed, nature of job
Exceptions: Positions where law prohibits hiring with certain convictions
Violations: Civil penalties, damages
laws.suggestion: Review Colorado background checks requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Colorado has comprehensive paid family and medical leave through FAMLI (Family and Medical Leave Insurance). Provides up to 12 weeks paid leave for most reasons, 16 weeks for pregnancy complications. Funded through payroll tax. Colorado also has Healthy Families and Workplaces Act requiring paid sick leave.
laws.notes: Colorado has comprehensive paid leave system. FAMLI is state-run insurance program. Very employee-friendly.
laws.law_citation: C.R.S. § 8-13.3-501 et seq. (FAMLI); C.R.S. § 8-13.3-401 et seq. (Healthy Families and Workplaces Act)
laws.full_text:
FAMLI (effective January 1, 2024): Provides up to 12 weeks paid leave per year
FAMLI: 16 weeks for pregnancy/childbirth complications
FAMLI: Covers: serious health condition, family member care, childbirth, adoption, safe leave (domestic violence, stalking, sexual assault), military family leave
FAMLI: Employees earn 90% of average weekly wage up to cap
FAMLI: Funded by payroll tax (approximately 0.9% split between employer/employee)
FAMLI: Applies to most Colorado employees who earned $2,500+ in previous year
FAMLI: Employers with 10+ employees must participate (smaller employers may opt in)
HEALTHY FAMILIES ACT: Employers must provide paid sick leave
HEALTHY FAMILIES ACT: Employees accrue 1 hour per 30 hours worked
HEALTHY FAMILIES ACT: Employers with 16+ employees: up to 48 hours per year
HEALTHY FAMILIES ACT: Employers with fewer than 16: up to 48 hours per year
HEALTHY FAMILIES ACT: Can use after first day of work (no waiting period)
HEALTHY FAMILIES ACT: Use for: illness, injury, medical care, public health emergency, domestic violence situations
Records must be maintained
Retaliation prohibited
laws.suggestion: Review Colorado paid leave requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Colorado enforces arbitration agreements under federal and state law but with some employee protections. Follows Federal Arbitration Act. Colorado Uniform Arbitration Act governs. Must be fair and not waive substantive rights.
laws.effective_date: Ongoing under federal and state law
laws.notes: Colorado enforces arbitration but with employee protections. Must be procedurally fair.
laws.law_citation: Federal Arbitration Act (9 U.S.C. §§ 1-16); C.R.S. § 13-22-201 et seq. (Uniform Arbitration Act)
laws.full_text:
Arbitration agreements generally enforceable under FAA
Must be in writing and clearly presented
Must have mutual agreement to arbitrate
Must identify claims subject to arbitration
Cannot be unconscionable
Must provide for neutral arbitrator
Cannot impose unreasonable costs on employee
Adequate consideration required
Colorado courts scrutinize arbitration agreements for fairness
Class action waivers generally enforceable but may be challenged
Pre-dispute arbitration agreements enforceable if fair
Can be challenged on unconscionability grounds
Federal policy favoring arbitration applies
laws.suggestion: Review Colorado arbitration requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Colorado follows at-will employment doctrine with exceptions. Either party can terminate employment for any legal reason. Exceptions exist for discrimination, retaliation, public policy violations, and breach of contract. Colorado has strong anti-discrimination protections.
laws.notes: Colorado has broader employee protections than many at-will states. Protections for off-duty lawful activities including marijuana use.
laws.law_citation: Common law doctrine; C.R.S. § 24-34-401 et seq. (Colorado Anti-Discrimination Act - CADA)
laws.full_text:
Default: Employment terminable at will by either party
No notice required unless contract/policy requires it
Final wages must be paid immediately if terminated, or by next payday if employee quits
EXCEPTIONS - Cannot terminate for: Disability, race, creed, color, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression, religion, age 40+, national origin, ancestry, pregnancy, childbirth (CADA - very broad)
Cannot terminate for: Retaliation (whistleblowing, workers' comp, wage claims, jury duty, voting, military service)
Cannot terminate for: Lawful off-duty activities (C.R.S. § 24-34-402.5 - smoking, lawful products, lawful activities)
Cannot terminate for: Marijuana use outside work (with exceptions for safety-sensitive positions or federal requirements)
Cannot terminate for: Violation of public policy
Cannot terminate for: Breach of employment contract
Employment handbooks may create enforceable obligations
Written employment contracts override at-will status
Union/collective bargaining agreements override at-will status
laws.suggestion: Review Colorado at will employment requirements and ensure compliance.

laws.summary: Colorado restricts drug testing for marijuana. C.R.S. § 24-34-402.5 protects lawful off-duty activities including marijuana use. Employers cannot discriminate based on off-duty marijuana use unless it affects job performance or safety. Exceptions for safety-sensitive positions and federal requirements.
laws.effective_date: Marijuana protections: 2012 (Amendment 64); Clarified through case law and guidance
laws.notes: Colorado has strongest marijuana employee protections. Cannot discriminate for off-duty use unless safety-sensitive. Testing must show impairment, not just use. Coats v. Dish Network (2015) initially allowed termination but law evolved.
laws.full_text:
Cannot terminate for lawful off-duty marijuana use (with exceptions)
EXCEPTIONS: Can prohibit marijuana use and test for: safety-sensitive positions, positions subject to federal background checks/federal contracts/federal licensing, positions requiring operation of vehicles/machinery, positions where impairment could adversely affect safety
Must have reasonable suspicion of impairment to test during work hours
Pre-employment testing: Allowed but positive marijuana test alone cannot be sole basis for rejection (unless exception applies)
Random testing: Limited to safety-sensitive positions
Cannot test based solely on smell of marijuana
Must establish observable impairment, not just positive test
Testing technology issue: Tests detect past use, not current impairment
Federal contractors: Must comply with Drug-Free Workplace Act
DOT-regulated positions: Must follow federal testing requirements
Recommended: Clear written policy defining safety-sensitive positions
Medical marijuana: Same protections as recreational
Workers' comp: May be affected by positive drug test
laws.suggestion: Review Colorado drug screening requirements and ensure compliance.
